Description: Rim sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; pinkish creamy slip; interior glazed black with ornate lotus flower in added red and white; exterior slip mostly worn: part of glazed (fired brown) band at rim above band of short diagonal strokes; at bottom of sherd, part of band(?) in red; painted inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Lemos the sherd belongs to a kantharos, but the large diameter is uncommon on kantharoi. Whilst painted inscriptions are typically found on kantharoi, they are sometimes also found on other cups.
Bibliographic references: Cook & Woodhead 1952 / Painted Inscriptions on Chiot Pottery (p. 165, no. 24)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 736, no. 965)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 296, no. 976)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 33, no. 10, pl. XVII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1195) (phase 2)
